qas.question: When did the slave trade hit the CAR region?
What is one area where captive slaves were sent?
Which people were major slave traders in the 19th century?
Who did the Bobangi sell slave to?
What river saw the establishment of a new Kingdom?
During the 16th and 17th centures what group began to raid the region?
What did the Bobangi people establish in the 18th century along the Ubangi River?

plausible_answers.text: as part of the expansion of the Saharan and Nile River slave routes

qas.question: Why did the Bandia-Nzakara raid the region in the 16th and 17th centuries?

plausible_answers.text: the Mediterranean coast, Europe, Arabia, the Western Hemisphere

qas.question: What are some areas where the Bobangi were shipped along the slave routes?

plausible_answers.text: along the West and North Africa or South the Ubanqui and Congo rivers

qas.question: Where were the Bandia-Nzakara slave ports and factories located?

context: During the <a0_0>16th and 17th centuries<a0_0/> slave traders began to raid the region <b7_0>as part of the expansion of the Saharan and Nile River slave routes<b7_0/>. Their captives were slaved and shipped to <b8_0>the Mediterranean coast, <a1_0>Europe<a1_0/>, Arabia, the Western Hemisphere<b8_0/>, or to the slave ports and factories <b9_0>along the West and North Africa or South the Ubanqui and Congo rivers<b9_0/>. In the mid 19th century, <b5_0>the <a2_0>Bobangi people<b5_0/><a2_0/> became major slave traders and sold their captives to <a3_0>the Americas<a3_0/> using the Ubangi river to reach the coast. During the 18th century Bandia-Nzakara peoples established <b6_0>the Bangassou Kingdom<b6_0/> along the <a4_0>Ubangi River<a4_0/>.
